title: unite unions crack squad wins
story: Exclusive: Unite unions crack squad wins breakthrough % pay deals for lorry driversLorry drivers get up to  per cent pay rises in breakthrough deals after the Unite union sets up a special disputes unit to avert Christmas supply chain crisisA shortage of lorry drivers is causing havoc with deliveries to shops and other businesses Image: Getty ImagesByChris McLaughlinPolitical reporter:,  Nov | commentsA new union “crack squad” has won breakthrough pay deals for lorry ­drivers crucial to keeping pre-­Christmas supply chains open. Transport workers’ union Unite has secured wage rises of up to % for truckers delivering food, gts and supermarket products. A string of victories over the past two months is credited to the creation of the union’s “special disputes unit”. It has been central to settlements including: - % for  HGV drivers at a logistics hub company in Chippenham, Wiltshire - A .% rise and paid meal breaks for  Liverpool tanker drivers delivering bulk liquid food products - A hike from £. an hour to £ for more than  Argos drivers in the North West, taking annual earnings from £, to £,.  Colleagues have put the results down to new general secretary Sharon Graham, who pledged to target the union’s resources on winning disputes. She also set up the crack team hub. It includes specialist and local negotiators and aims to settle strikes or threatened industrial action in critical sectors . Ms Graham said: “These results are an excellent reflection of how the union intends to focus all its energy and willpower in the future on fighting for jobs, pay and conditions for our members. It’s early days but the special unit I set up is already beginning to bear fruit.”  Unite also said at least  cement lorry drivers, who are essential for the building industry, will get rises of .% backdated to the start of the year plus .% from January. Other above-inflation deals have been ­secured with Heinz, Sainsbury’s, naval bases and for refuse workers in London. Strike action that could have halted car production at BMW Mini in Oxford was recently averted when Unite drivers for a components firm were awarded % over two years. More than  workers at a global engineering firm in Cambridge have won the right to union negotiating rights for the first time. The successes follow a critical lack of lorry drivers, threatening festive supply shortages.Ministers have blamed Covid, an exodus of overseas operators following Brexit and low wages in the industry. Hauliers complain of a shortage of new recruits and delays in the issuing of new training licences by the DVLA.Comment MORE ON UniteSupermarketsChristmasSunday People" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: britains youngest great grandmother 51
story: Exclusive: Britains youngest great grandmother, , feels blessed despite cancer battleNicky Dando had her first daughter aged  and is now a great grandma to baby Maliki aged just  - her cousin is Good Morning Britains weatherman Alex BeresfordNicky - Britains youngest great grandmother - considers herself blessed despite fighting breast cancer Image: TIM ANDERSONBySarah Robertson:,  Nov | commentsBrave Nicky Dando reckons she holds the title of Britain’s youngest great-gran… after her grandson became a dad when she was just . But Nicky’s joy over her ever-growing family has been bittersweet as she is battling breast cancer. Yet as her family rally round – including her cousin, Good Morning Britain weatherman Alex Beresford – Nicky says she considers herself blessed. She said: “Not many live to see grandchildren, let alone great-grandchildren. “My little munchie is a blessing sent from above. When I’m with them all we have so much fun and laughter.”For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Nicky – who had the first of her two children at  – said of her long line of descendents: ”I can’t find any sign of a great-grandmother younger than me. When we researched it, there was a woman in Wales who was .” That is three years older than Nicky was when her first great-grandchild, Maliki Kennett-Miles, put in an appearance in December . The average age to become a grand parent is , with women becoming mums on average at . Nicky, now , has six grandkids – and Maliki’s dad, car technician Tyrese, was her first.  When he was born in January , Nicky was just . That makes her younger than Gemma Skinner, reported last month to be Britain’s youngest gran at . Tyrese was just  when he first became a father. His mum was Nicky’s first child, born in , who was just  when she had Tyrese. Nicky says: “I remember thinking, ‘No way, I’m only ! But I was only  when I was a grandmother. I’m fit enough despite my health to enjoy them – and they’re proud when their friends say, ‘Who’s the girl with you, hook me up’, and they tell them, ‘That’s my nanny!’” Nicky, from Bristol, first found signs of the cancer in December , with a burning sensation in her left armpit.She then discovered a breast lump – and is now being kept alive by a course of drug treatments costing the NHS £, every three months.But she is determined to use her time to raise money for a new scan and radiotherapy machine to help others, and has set up a Gofundme page.  TV cousin Alex, who presents the magazine show All Around Britain, has offered his support. Nicky added: “It’s been a lot for the family to deal with. Alex makes me proud – I watch him and he makes me so proud.” To find out more, and help Nicky’s campaign, search online for Nicola Dando at GoFundMe. title: cps pursues russian mob over
story: Exclusive: CPS pursues Russian mob over £.million diamonds stolen by woman in granny disguiseLulu Lakatos aged , was jailed after posing as a gem expert granny and swapping diamonds for pebbles in £.m heist of Boodles in Mayfair and now the CPS wants to recover the haul from the Russian mobLulu Lakatos was caught on CCTV at the Cricklewood Lodge Hotel in north London Image: PAByDominik Lemanski:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsInvestigators are having another go at recovering loot from Britain’s biggest jewellery heist. Russian mobsters are believed to be behind the raid in which a woman in a granny disguise stole £.million of diamonds – ­swapping them for pebbles. Not a penny has been recovered from the  snatch at Boodles in Mayfair, West London.The Sunday People can now reveal that the Crown Prosecution Service has started a new legal battle to claw back the proceeds.But it was warned the effort could be an uphill struggle. A source said: “The police reckon the gems have already been re-cut and sold on, so they will be very hard to trace. The Russian mobsters behind this were well resourced and meticulous. There’s little hope of the authorities recovering the diamonds or the cash made from their sale.”  An international manhunt for the gang is still ongoing, despite three being nabbed. Jewel thief Lulu Lakatos, , was jailed for five-and-a-half years in July. Using sleight of hand, she switched gems for rocks of the same weight while pretending to carry out a valuation for wealthy Russian buyers. The crook – a former cleaner and school catering assistant in her native Romania – managed to hand the purse to two women walking past outside. Neither has ever been traced.  Lakatos dumped her disguise in a Wetherspoon’s pub toilet before fleeing via the Channel Tunnel. Boodles discovered the theft the next day when staff opened the safe and found small garden pebbles. The real diamonds – including a £.m, .-carat stone cut in a heart shape – have never been recovered. The only hint of them being traded on the open market came in , when detectives believed one may have turned up at a Belgian jewellery store.  Its unusual size arose suspicion but the paperwork did not match. Lakatos was tracked on CCTV by police after she boarded a Eurostar train to Paris. She was arrested in France in September last year. Two other raiders, Christophe Stankovic, , and Mickael Jovanovic, , were jailed for three years and eight months last year after being convicted of conspiracy to steal. The CPS declined to comment on the matter except to confirm that confiscation proceedings are due to start at Southwark crown court in February.  Justice campaigners welcomed the move to pursue the gang. David Spencer at the Centre of Crime Prevention added: “It is absolutely right that the CPS is going after this criminal gang to recover the goods it stole. “Too often we see criminals getting to keep all or most of their stolen assets, even when convicted of the crime. “It is refreshing to see that is not the case in this instance and the CPS should pursue every avenue to recover these stolen gems or any financial gain these crooks have made selling them.” Comment MORE ON CrimeSunday PeopleJewelleryThe Mafia" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: dad four 35 who thought
story: Dad-of-four, , who thought his cough was coronavirus dies of lung cancerDaniel Muir, who worked as a chef and played guitar in a band, died at his home in Anglesey, Wales following a short and brutal battle with lung cancerDaniel Muir, from Anglesey in Wales, was just  when he died after a short and gruelling battle with lung cancer Image: Nerys MuirByAnnie OwenRyan FaheyReporter:,  Nov | comments A dad-of-four who thought his cough was Covid has died of cancer aged . Chef and guitarist Daniel Muir, from Anglesey in Wales, died at home on October  following a short and gruelling battle with lung cancer. His heartbroken we Nerys has now spoken of her grief in the hopes it may help others to detect tumours earlier, Wales Onlin e reports.The young mum said her loss is often too hard to talk about but hopes that by sharing Danielaposs story she will make her late husband proud.She said: “All you need to get lung cancer is lungs. “My husband didnapost smoke and there is no way we would have ever have thought it would be something serious. “Even Daniel’s lung doctor was devastated and shocked- in his  years of working the field he has never met someone as young as Daniel with such an aggressive form of cancer. “Itaposs important no one goes through watching their loved one disappear in front of them by something like this.” Nerys says she feels angry that the cruel disease was not detected earlier and urged others to learn how to detect symptoms. She said: “Lung cancer is always thought to be something smokers get, or the elderly. “Iaposm angry and Iaposm sad that we thought the scariest thing it could be was Covid.” Daniel first developed a cough in November , and they both thought it could be down to work stress. When it worsened, they feared it could be Covid, but never imagined it couldaposve been cancer. It wasnapost until a month after Daniel began experiencing back pain that he went to a GP. A series of appointments later and he was diagnosed with stage four lung cancer.  The lung tumour had already spread to his pelvis and spine but the couple were hopeful as he had age on his side. “He’s the bravest man Iaposve ever known,” she said. He then went through gruelling courses of chemo and radiotherapy, but none were effective and he was told there was nothing more that could be done. It was  days later that Daniel passed away, leaving behind his daughters Ava, , Izzy, , who live with their mum in Kent, and six-year-old son Elijah, who he shared with Nerys. He was also stepdad to Nerysapos biological son Nathaniel, who he treated as his own. Nerys said her husband’s biggest fear was leaving his four children and that he spoke about them in his final few moments. She said: “When Daniel was taking his final breaths I promised him I would take care of all the children. “He wouldnapost show anyone his struggle through his sickness so no one realised how bad things were, except for me, because I was with him every day caring for him. “He was scared of dying so chose not to talk about it.”A Go Fund Me page has been set up to raise money for the children called make the children smile.Nerys explained: “Daniel didnapost have insurance, thereaposs no savings or anything, his biggest fear was leaving the children. “He was scared that his sons who live in Anglesey wouldnapost be able to see his daughters who live in Kent without him. “But myself and their mother have come together to make sure that we can do things together.”Daniel, who worked as a chef at Catch  Brasserie in Holyhead, was also passionate about music and played in a band called The Submission.In the months before he passed away he performed with his band, raising almost £, for Cancer Research and the Alaw ward at Ysbyty Gwynedd where he had been receiving treatment. title: dad prince harrys tragic former
story: Exclusive: Dad of Prince Harrys tragic former comrade begs please help us honour our sonA family begs Prince Harry to intervene after MoD rejects calls to add PTSD Afghanistan veteran Nathan Hunt to a list of soldiers names on the Armed Forces MemorialNathan Hunt, who died in , served in Afghanistan Image: Jon CorkenBySean Rayment:,  Nov | commentsPrince Harry has been urged to help the family of a tragic former comrade to get the lasting honour he deserves. Nathan Hunt served alongside the Duke of Sussex and saved the lives of many comrades in Afghanistan. But after he went on to develop post traumatic stress, he was tragically found hanged at his home. His grieving family were then told Nathan’s name will not be added to the national Armed Forces Memorial after defence chiefs ruled his death was not directly linked to his service. Today his mum and dad, Derek and Maria Hunt, share the letter they have written to the prince in the hope he can help them force a U-turn. In the moving document, they tell Harry they are “heartbroken”. They add: “Nathan was a dedicated professional soldier who gave everything in the service of his country. “We believe he was a casualty of war and he died of mental wounds sustained during his service in Afghanistan. You have always been a champion of veterans and we hope that your influence might help the Ministry of Defence to change its policy and add Nathan’s name to the memorial wall.” Nathan served alongside Harry in  in Helmand as part of a desert reconnaissance unit. His role was to locate bombs planted by the Taliban. He was a Royal Engineers Warrant Officer when he died aged .  His parents – who met Harry and we Meghan in  – insist Nathan should be included on the Armed Forces Memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum, which contains names of more than , killed in action or from disease since the end of the Second World War. The names of three other soldiers who served in Afghanistan and died after taking their own lives are engraved on the memorial in Staffordshire.Grieving Derek told the Sunday People : “Nathan’s medical reports show his condition deteriorated after he ed from Afghanistan. “So we just don’t understand why the MoD are basically saying there is no connection between what he experienced there and his mental health. “He was a dedicated soldier who spent  years in the Army. He risked his le almost every day in Afghanistan and his actions saved the lives of many soldiers. Nathan’s job was to find bombs and he did it brilliantly, often under fire from the Taliban. But it took a toll. Nathan might not have come back with physical injuries, but he was mentally wounded. “And those mental wounds took his le. As far as we are concerned, he was a casualty of war.”  The dad added: “Everyone who worked with Nathan knew he was selfless and committed. “The very least the Ministry of Defence could do would be to add his name to the war memorial so that our family and his descendants will be able to see the sacrice he made in the service of his country.“ Prince Harry appreciated the sacrice that Nathan made. It’s just a shame the MoD can’t do the same. I can’t understand why they are being so heartless.” Defence chiefs ruled in May that Nathan’s name should not be included on the memorial. Derek,  and Maria, , from Lincoln, appealed but that was turned down in September. Lieutenant General James Swt wrote to the couple stating “on the balance of probabilities”, their son’s death could not be attributed to his service. A psychiatric report produced after Nathan died said he experienced “traumatic exposure” in Afghanistan and had “some elements of PTSD.” An inquest found he had died from hanging. During his six months in Afghanistan the soldier received a Mention in Dispatches. The citation for his award described him as “a ­superb example of leadership, professionalism and a fantastic ambassador to his corps.” The MoD said: “Careful consideration is given to each case and the decision not to include WO Hunt’s name on the Armed Forces Memorial does not detract from his service in the Army. We are eternally grateful.” The Sunday People’s Save Our Soldiers campaign is fighting to give those who come back from war zones the care they need and deserve. title: fully game queen floors tom
story: Exclusive: Fully game Queen floors Tom Daley by joking she should try gymnasticsOlympic gold er Tom Daley said the Queen was fully game to get involved with gymnastics and even revealed it was her secret passion when he met her in Gymnast Matt Whitlock revealed she was a fan when she told him she loved watching the sport on the television Image: Getty ImagesByHalina Watts:,  Nov | commentsThe Queen floored ing star Tom Daley by jokingly saying she could be a gymnast. Her Majesty’s quip came as she met Tom and fellow Olympians. Gold medal-winning Tom, , revealed: “She commented on her height compared to some of the other athletes in the room and because me and the other athletes were quite small, she said, ‘Maybe I should try gymnastics’. “She was fully game to get involved in the sport.”The exchange came in  when the Queen, , hosted a Buckingham Palace reception also attended by her late husband Prince Philip and other royals. The monarch revealed her passion for gymnastics again in  when she presented the MBE to double Olympic champ Max Whitlock. He said Her Majesty told him she “loved watching the gymnastics because the stuff that we do doesn’t seem possible”. That was a reference to body bending disciplines like the beam and acrobatics. Max, , said at the time: “It was pretty cool to hear the Queen say she likes the sport.” The monarch, currently on light duties on doctors’ advice, regularly attends sporting events and is a horse racing enthusiast – and rider. Tom’s revelation came on the Swedish chat show Skavlan.For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here.Comment MORE ON The QueenTom DaleyMax WhitlockRoyal FamilyGymnasticsSunday Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news grieving-woman-loses-everything-stray-"Womans house set alight after stray firework lands in back gardenByBradley JollyNews Wire:,  Nov | comments A grieving pensioner has lost everything after a stray firework ripped through her home last night. Pauline Perry, , avoided serious injury in the ordeal, but was traumatised after the stray firework initially landed in her garden and caused her rattan furniture to catch fire.When the blaze caused her patio door to pop, Pauline opened the doors and desperately tried to move the furniture away from her home.But this caused the fire to shoot through her living room and destroy the downstairs, reports Liverpool Echo. Four fire engines dashed to the property in Norris Green, Liverpool, on Bonfire Night at around .pm. The homeowneraposs neighbour, Steve Finlay, who took Pauline in last night after the fire services boarded up her home, said she had not spotted the growing fire as her curtains had been closed at the time. Steve, , said: After the fire ripped through the living room, the neighbours spotted the flames and ran over to get Pauline out of the house and help. Pauline, who is originally from Wolverhampton, West Midlands, moved to Liverpool with her husband around six years ago and has since spoken about how much she loves the area and community.But her partner died in September after being admitted to hospital with sepsis. Steve continued: “She was only just readjusting after her husband’s passing and then for this to happen - there’s just no justice. “I know Pauline has the same views as me when it comes to fireworks already and that is we should no longer be selling them. Only organised displays should be allowed and there should be a stop on selling fireworks to households. “It isn’t acceptable.” Steve said that the community all came together to help Pauline last night. He added: “We have a great little community but we all just done what normal people would do.” Alistair Smith, a local from a neighbouring street has since set up a GoFundMe page in a bid to raise money to help Pauline get back on her feet. He said: “Pauline is okay but just in a bad state. “We’re hoping to raise some money in the community just to help her through it all - every little helps.”  A spokesman for Merseyside Fire and Rescue confirmed that the fire was caused by a stray firework and the incident was not a targeted attack. They said: “Firefighters arrived to find the ground floor of a two-storey detached property well alight and committed  teams of two firefighters, with a hose reel jet each, one team fighting fire, the other searching the house for occupants. “One occupant was out of the property when crews arrived and an ambulance was requested for precautionary checks. “The fire was under control by .pm and crews continued to search the building before firefighting ceased at .pm. Crews continued to damp down and remained on scene until .pm. “An investigation revealed that the fire had been caused by a stray firework igniting garden furniture which had then spread to the property. “ Comment MORE ON FireFireworksBonfire Night" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: horrified woman spiked injection night
story: Horried woman spiked by injection on night out initially dismissed it as a cutChloe Madico, , went out for a pals birthday to Popworld in Guilford, Surrey and woke up the next morning with a mark on her leg and realising she couldnt remember a huge part of the nightChloe Madico says she was spiked when she went out for a pals birthday to Popworld in Guilford, Surrey Image: Chloe Madico Surrey LiveByMegan StanleyAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA woman says she was spiked by injection but had dismissed it as being a cut. Chloe Madico, , went out for a palaposs birthday to Popworld on October  in Guilford, Surrey where she said she was surrounded by school friends the entire night.Chloe was shocked when she woke up the next morning with a mark on her leg and realising she couldnapost remember a huge part of the night, SurreyLive reports.She said: I have no recollection of the night whatsoever, my friend had to tell me a lot of the stuff that happened.I just assumed I was just really drunk, even though Iaposd never experienced anything like that. I was apparently dead weight, I was falling to the floor, I couldnapost string a sentence together.  Chloe added: When we saw the mark on my leg in the morning, we just assumed I had cut myself. When she ed to Bournemouth, where she now lives, her flatmates said they saw similar marks on social media with reports of others being injected. She continued: At first as I was just aposoh it will be fineapos but my flatmate was insisting I go to the hospital. Nurses and doctors at Royal Bournemouth Hospital confirmed it looked like an injection mark.  Chloe says now she needs to get multiple blood tests, vaccinations and trips to the hospital and a sexual health clinic to make sure she has not caught anything from the needle that spiked her. Chloeaposs ordeal comes as police forces around the UK have received a growing number of reports of people being spiked in bars and nightclubs around the country, with some allegedly being targeted with needle injections. The increase in reports and accounts has led to some institutions ramping up their efforts to keep patrons safe. for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information atwww.mirror email. Some pubs have installed led aposairport-styleapos security at the doors and others have scrapped aposladiesapos nightapos over safety concerns.The spiking reports also led to a national movement to boycott clubs, which was organised by university students. Chloe now hopes to raise awareness for anyone to see medical attention as soon as they can. She continued: The only reason I went to hospital was because a girl I lived with sent me a social media post - I just thought it was a cut and kept saying I would be fine. If she hadnapost convinced me, I would have been sat here thinking it was a cut on my leg. I was so shocked at the time I had no idea, thataposs why I didnapost go straight to AE. Looking back now I know I definitely needed to. Chloe says that although she felt safe going out she believes establishments could make improvements to make it safer. She said: No disrespect to Popworld, but they couldaposve done more on entry. I know itaposs hard to bag search everyone but they were just doing spot checks rather than everyone.  I know it might take longer to get people in and it could cause bigger queues but I do think they need to up their game. A spokesperson for Popworld said: The safety of our guests and our team, has always been, and remains our number one priority and we continually review our safety and security procedures to ensure our customers and staff remain safe. We treat all allegations of spiking seriously and ask customers to bring this to our attention immediately should they have concerns their drinks have been tampered with.Advice and guidance on spiking, both drink and injection, is available from Talk to Frank.The organisation says:If you start to feel strange, sick or drunk when you know that you couldn’t be drunk, seek help from a trusted friend or the venue management.If you think you have been spiked, get a close friend to get you out of the place as soon as possible and take you home or to hospital . Or ring a friend, relative or partner and ask them to come and pick you up.If you feel unsafe, vulnerable or threatened you can ask for help by approaching venue staff and asking them for ‘Angela’. This code-phrase indicates to staff that you need help and a trained member of staff will then support and assist you.Make sure you can trust the person you ask for help, and don’t go anywhere with a stranger or acquaintance.Once you are safely home ask someone to stay with you until the effects of the drug have worn off, which could be several hours.Call for medical helpyou need it and tell the police what happened. “We are aware there is increasing concern over alleged increases in spiking in clubs and bars and have therefore enhanced our measures and employed Guest Support to assist any guests that are feeling vulnerable or unwell. These team members are easily identiable, as they wear a neon armband. We have enhanced security checks on our door, and we ask guests to remain vigilant and report any unusual or suspicious behaviour to one of our team immediately. A Surrey Police spokesperson added: We received a report of spiking by injection over the weekend commencing Friday, October . The victim is receiving ongoing medical care and support from family and friends. This is the first such report of needle spiking that we have received in Guildford, although we do occasionally receive reports of drink spiking. Our Divisional Drugs Liaison Officers and Licensing Officers work closely with nightclubs and bars to raise awareness of this issue, including giving advice to the venueaposs staff on how to recognise the signs in someone whose drink has been spiked, and what to do in that situation. We will continue to liaise and work with them in relation to this latest issue. We would encourage anyone who believes they have been a victim or witness to spiking, in any form, to contact their local police force as soon as possible. Any reports of spiking will be investigated and taken seriously. news uk-news idris-elba-says-meghan-harry-"Royal Wedding: Idris Elba arrives for the ceremony in ByBradley JollyNews Wire:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsMeghan Markle allegedly told Idris Elba what songs he should play in his DJ set at her and Prince Harryaposs wedding.The Luther star, , today claimed the royal sent him a playlist ahead of the- despite Elbaaposs extensive experience DJing at celebrity parties, including queen of pop Madonna and even collaborated on a track with Sir Paul McCartney. But the esteemed actor admitted the wedding celebration - on May ,  at Frogmore House in Windsor, Berkshire - was his most stressful DJ gig. This wasn’t at the community hall — the reception. This was a big, big deal, Elba, who grew up in London, said.  Meghan had sent me a playlist, so I knew what she wanted already. They’re good friends and I wanted to make sure they had a great time, so there was a lot of pressure.Elba, who made his name in US crime drama series The Wire, has also performed DJ sets at Ibiza superclubs and huge festivals around the world, reports Mail Online.But dad-of-two Elba, who is a big Arsenal fan, entertained some global superstars at the royal wedding.  While showbusiness friends, including George Clooney and James Corden, were invited, some of Harry’s oldest friends were left wondering why they hadn’t made the guest list. Tom Inskip — known by his friends as ‘Skippy’ - did not get an invite. Harry had been best friends with the man for years.Elbaaposs revelation comes amid claims Meghan and Harry are planning to carry out more fake royal tours next year. Royal commentator Neil Sean has claimed the couple will visit Australia and Japan in , despite critics questioning what their new role has become since breaking away from the Royal Family. Speaking on his YouTube podcast, the royal expert said: According to a very good source, Harry and Meghan are planning even more, shall we say, aposfake royal toursapos in . Apparently they are looking to tour Australia, Japan and back to certain areas of the United States. Sean suggested that Harry and Meghan are “not that popular right now” and that “maybe they’re hoping to reignite their once popularity in far-flung places.” Comment MORE ON Royal FamilyMeghan MarklePrince Harry and Meghan Markle weddingPrince HarryIdris Elba" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: joy mum inspirational boy 6
story: Joy for Bradley Lowrys mum as she celebrates birth of baby girlGemma and Carl Lowery welcomed Gracie-Mae four years after their son Bradley died of cancer, aged six - they have already said he is the  angel to his little brother or sisterGemma and Carl Lowery welcomed Gracie-Mae at .am on November ByNicole GoodwinAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsThe mum of an inspirational boy who died of cancer has given birth to a baby girl. Gemma and Carl Lowery welcomed Gracie-Mae at .am on November .She was born via emergency cesarian at Sunderland Royal hospital and is believed to be doing well , ChronicleLive reports.In a Facebook post, Gemma said she didnapost have the best of labour, but their daughter was now doing amazing. When the parents first announced the pregnancy, they also paid tribute to their son Bradley who died in July  saying he is theangel to his little brother or sister. Sunderland fan Bradley was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a type of cancer found mainly in babies and young children, at the age of just  months. The six-year-old captured the hearts of the nation and he struck up a friendship with then Black Cats striker Jermain Defoe and was a mascot for Sunderland.Bradley was even named joint winner of the December  BBC Goal of the Month for a penalty he took against Cha. The coupleaposs post read: Hi everyone just an update to welcome our beautul little princess to the world. Gracie-Mae was born :am on th November weighing lb. I didnapost have the best of labour but Iaposll not bore you all with the details. I had to have an emergency C section as her heart rate dropped and they needed her out. She is now doing amazing and we are on our way home. I want to say a huge shout out to all the staff on the maternity unit at Sunderland Royal hospital. Every single one of them from start of care when I fell pregnant to leaving tonight have been incredible. Myself and Carl are going to now enjoy some family time with our beautul princess.  I know everyone will be eager to see her, and I’ll be sharing some pictures soon, but we want all the family to meet her first. Thank you all for your support. In September, two streets were named in honour of Bradley. Bradley Lowery Way leading to Sunshine Place is part of the new Hardwicke Place development in Blackhall Colliery, County Durham, close to his familyaposs home. Sunshine was the nickname Gemma and husband Carl gave Bradley, due to his sunny disposition despite the pain and discomfort he was suffering throughout his illness. title: meet community groups government hopes
story: Meet the community groups Government hopes can tackle countrys health and wellbeing crisisUp and down the country community groups are aiming to tackle the country’s health crisis in the wake of the pandemic with singing, poetry, gardening and paracise exercise classesMost people with conditions like pulmonary fibrosis had to find support groups themselves by in  the NHS committed to hiring , special coordinators helping doctors prescribe activities Image: Getty Images MaskotByElizabeth Archer:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsAs Christine Cole belted out the lyrics to her favourite song, a huge smile spread across her face. She was finally back at her weekly choir meeting, after months of online sessions only during lockdown. But this isn’t any choir – it’s a special singing group, Shared Harmonies, for people with respiratory problems. For Christine, who has pulmonary fibrosis, it’s a leline. “It’s brilliant,” says Christine, , a retired secretary who lives in Drighlington, West Yorks, with her husband David, . “You meet new people. You make friends and are able to talk to people who really understand your problems.” Until now, most people with conditions like pulmonary fibrosis had to find such support groups themselves by searching online or contacting charities. But in , the NHS committed to hiring , special coordinators by March  – helping doctors prescribe activities like gardening groups, community choirs and fitness classes.Now, the Government hopes community groups can help tackle the country’s health and wellbeing crisis in the wake of the pandemic. Emma Baylin, a former NHS volunteer coordinator, welcomes the changes. “It’s positive the NHS sees the value in social prescribing. It can help with early intervention and prevention for a host of wellbeing and health issues,” she says. “I’ve seen first-hand people who have reduced their dependence on NHS services through accessing community groups.”  Nicola Harker, a le coach and former NHS GP , agrees. While working as a GP, she once took the unusual decision to prescribe poetry writing to a patient who had suffered a stroke and was struggling to express himself verbally. “It’s hugely valuable. This particular patient was very frustrated but traditional medication wouldn’t have been able to help. It almost brought me to tears to see how his le changed because he had a new vocation and he solved his communication dficulties,” she says. “While we have to be realistic that social prescribing can’t patch over the funding gaps in the NHS, it can certainly help. “I’d like to see people on the waiting list for mental health services being connected with community projects in the meantime, or people going through cancer treatment finding groups which allow them to express their experiences.” Christine was diagnosed with pulmonary fibrosis in  after a persistent cough and breathlessness. At the time, she was given from three to five years to live. “It was devastating, but doctors have since found a cause for my condition and I’m still here  years later,” she says. She found out about Shared Harmonies online, and discovered a class a few miles away in Leeds. “We start by doing relaxation exercises, before deep breathing and stretching. Then we sing two or three simple, short songs with harmonies. “Sometimes we get things wrong and have a few laughs. I’ve made great friends over the years and couldn’t wait to get back to meeting in person after lockdown.” While Christine and her husband were lucky enough to find lots of local support groups online, she agrees more people would find groupsdoctors signposted patients to them. “I don’t know what I’d do without them,” she says. “I have friends locally who I can talk to but it’s not the same as speaking to someone who really understands what you’re going through.”  Christine goes for regular breathing tests and says singing every week has improved her lungby seven per cent. But it’s the emotional support she values most. “It’s so comforting knowing there are groups like this out there, and I think it’s great the NHS is going to start prescribing community classes more.” Avril Clerkson, who teaches fitness classes for people with limited mobility, is also thrilled about the NHS proposals. “People often think they won’t be able to exercise after surgery or being diagnosed with an illness, but we offer a class anybody can do regardless of mobility,” says Avril, , who lives in Addiewell, West Lothian, with husband Steven, . She found out about Paracise exercise classes after being diagnosed with breast cancer during a routine mammogram. She had a lumpectomy and some of her lymph nodes were removed, meaning she had limited movement in her left side and suffered from lymphedema, a fluid build-up in the body. “The diagnosis was a horrible shock and I’d always been very active so it was great to find a class I could still do after my surgery.”  Since starting the classes, she has regained full movement in her left side and the swelling in her left arm is greatly reduced. Now she teaches Paracise classes and has seen the benefits for others too.In lockdown, she could be found bouncing around in her kitchen teaching classes on Facebook.“A lot of people were saying they lived alone and were missing the company Paracise brings,” she says. “So I kept the groups going online and it was a godsend for a lot of people.”The Scottish health service already refers people to her classes for a range of health conditions, including arthritis, fibromyalgia and stroke. And she is glad social prescribing is becoming more widespread.“Classes like this can help prevent people having falls at home, help faster recovery from surgery, and can prevent some people needing mental health services, which eases the NHS burden.” For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here.Aishah Iqbal has psoriasis and says community groups helped her cope with the condition in lockdown. “I’ve had it for  years. It started during my GCSEs from stress and has impacted me at dferent points in my le,” says Aishah, , a paediatric doctor from Leicester. “It gets really itchy and has an impact on my ability to concentrate in the day and I don’t get much sleep at night so it’s a horrible cycle and hits my confidence.” During lockdown she suffered a particularly bad flare-up and turned to a community support group she found through Facebook. “When I wasn’t really getting much social interaction, I found it harder to fight the sad feelings brought on by my condition. “But having people around me who were going through something similar made me realise I wasn’t alone.” Aishah believes social prescribing can be a leline. “Stress and anxiety can make long-term health conditions much worse, so while medication can help, emotional support is important too. While the NHS is great, there are limits to what it can provide, so putting people in touch with community groups is a great idea.” ■For more information go to sharedharmonies or paracise Comment MORE ON NHSHospitalsMental healthPrescriptionsFitnessSunday MirrorCoronavirusFitness And Health" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: miracle baby never know tragic
story: Exclusive: Miracle baby will never know tragic mum who died after refusing Covid jab while pregnantThe distraught family of Saiqa Parveen from Birmingham have urged pregnant women for Gods sake - get the vaccine after she caught Covid and died in intensive care while carrying her fth childSaiqa Parveen, , died in intensive care after catching the virus while carrying her fth childByJohn Siddle:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov This beautul baby girl slumbers peacefully – unaware she will never meet her Covid victim mum. Saiqa Parveen, , who refused the jab while pregnant, died after Dua was saved by a ­caesarean. Today Saiqa’s brother begs mums-to-be: “For God’s sake, get the vaccine.The heartbroken family of the unvaccinated mum who died from Covid without getting to meet her newborn daughter have begged all pregnant women to get jabbed, Birmingham Live reports.Saiqa died in intensive care after catching the virus while carrying her fth child and before she went into hospital. Last night her distraught family told the Birmingham Live of their pain as they implored other expectant mums to get vaccinated. Releasing a picture of Saiqa fighting for le in hospital – and the beautul baby she never got to hold – brother Qayoum Mughal, , urged: “For God’s sake, get the vaccine.”Saiqa, from Birmingham, was eight months into her pregnancy when she fell ill in mid-September. She was offered a Covid shot in summer but insisted she wanted to wait until her baby was born. As her condition worsened, Saiqa was placed in intensive care and underwent an emergency caesarean section at full term on September . She died this week – leaving behind her husband Majid Ghafur, , and daughters Noor, , Imaan, , Hibbah, eight, and Ayesha, six – and without ever meeting newborn Dua Maryam. Qayoum revealed how Saiqa’s daughters made a heartbreaking final online FaceTime call just an hour before their mum died on November . He told the Sunday Mercury: “They said, ‘Get up mummy, we are waiting, we are missing you, we love you, why are you leaving us behind  Just get up’. They were praying and in tears.” One in five of the most critically ill Covid patients are unvaccinated pregnant women, NHS figures show.Since July, % of patients on special lung-bypass machines were expectant mums who had not had their first jab. Qayoum, a dad of four, said: “I strongly ask all people please get their vaccination, otherwise you will have a bad situation like we are facing. “Get the vaccine and avoid this sort of tragedy. The family is completely broken. There is such a big sadness.” Saiqa had no underlying health conditions and her pregnancy had been routine until she tested positive for Covid on September . Two days later she developed breathing problems and was taken by ambulance to Birmingham’s Heartlands Hospital. She was discharged six days later only to be admitted to Good Hope Hospital on September  with breathing dficulties. Qayoum said: “She was on oxygen and on September  she called my we at pm and said she had signed documents saying thather condition worsened, the doctors could operate to take the baby out. “My we said she sounded very tired and only spoke for a few minutes. That was the last conversation with any of us. “The next morning her husband phoned us and told us that she was on a ventilator and they were preparing to operate. At pm, the doctor called her husband and told him they had delivered a baby girl. “We did not see her because she was on a ventilator in intensive care. She never saw her daughter.”By now Saiqa was also battling le threatening sepsis, a hole in both her lungs, as well as pneumonia and other infections.Qayoum said: “They allowed her husband to see her on October  and the doctor said she was very ill. “The doctor was telling him to talk to her. She was sedated but could hear. “He was talking to her, telling her that her eldest daughter is asking you to get up and ‘where is her birthday gt’ and she is missing mum. As soon as he said this, there was one long tear coming from her eye. That was the first and last reaction we had from her on the ventilator.”  Saiqa died just before pm on Monday. Her death certicate records respiratory failure and Covid- pneumonitis as the cause. Qayoum, who has had Covid himself, said: “Her daughters ask, ‘When’s mummy coming back ’ Saiqa was the most caring person, she couldn’t live without her family. She was a lady of principle. “She cared for everybody and her mother is still alive. She was very hard working and a helpful lady.” He added: “Her husband is crying but he’s got to be strong for his daughters.” The Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation says all pregnant women should be offered a Covid jab after studies proved it is safe. Previously it was offered only to pregnant women in frontline health and care or to the extremely clinically vulnerable. More than , mums-to-be have had a first dose and around , a second. Data from over , Covid vaccinations in pregnancy in England and Scotland, and a further , in the US, show there has been no subsequent harm to the foetus or baby. England’s chief midwery officer Jacqueline Dunkley-Bent said: “The Covid- jab can keep you, your baby and your loved ones out of hospital.”For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here.Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON NHSHospitalsPregnancyGiving birthNewborn babyCoronavirusSunday PeopleCoronavirus vaccine" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news morgue-monster-david-fullers-horried-"David Fuller is arrested for historic murders of two womenByPatrick HillDan WarburtonReporter for the Sunday Mirror and People:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments A horried nurse has told of her two-year affair with morgue monster David Fuller, not knowing he had killed two women.The warped hospital electrician wooed the unsuspecting woman with cocktails and concert tickets. Then he dumped her for another nurse – all behind the back of his trusting we. Fuller, , would go on to abuse scores of bodies in two hospital mortuaries. But his mistress only learned of his grotesque offences when he faced court last week. She told the Sunday Mirror today: “To think I’m associated with someone who did something so terrible is awful. I’m very lucky he didn’t kill me.”  As MPs called for an inquiry into Fuller’s hospital access, the woman, whose identity we are protecting, also revealed:She lived in a studio flat just around the corner from his two victims in the Bedsit Murders. Fuller charmed her and seemed the “perfect gentleman”. They met at a hospital social club, he drank Archers and lemonade and once took her to a Beverley Craven pop concert. Fuller always appeared to be ice cool and “would never get angry”.The woman believed Fuller to be an “ordinary, quiet man” – yet he was an arrogant lothario who had affairs with at least two female colleagues during three marriages. She started dating Fuller in  when he was with second we. Three years earlier he had sexually assaulted and killed Wendy Knell, , and Caroline Pierce, , in Tunbridge Wells, Kent.  The woman, now happily married, said: “I was quite aware of the Bedsit Murders and I was very nervous about them. The murders were in my mind and a lot of young women’s minds. “Little did I know I was actually dating the person responsible. In the back of my mind I do still think, ‘Why was I spared ’ “I was in the right criteria in that I lived in the roads near where the girls worked, I had a bedsit and I was in my s.”  Fuller admitted his guilt last week, four days into a murder trial. It was then revealed in court that he had defiled up to  bodies in hospital morgues. His female victims ranged in age from nine to . The revelations have shaken Fuller’s ex to the core. She told the Sunday Mirror: “He was a perfect gentleman with me. I didn’t see a bad side to him at all.  “There was nothing to lead me to believe he’s the person we’ve now found him out to be now. “He never showed any perversion in bed. He was totally ordinary and normal. There was nothing at all. I still can’t believe that he could be capable and part of me still doesn’t want to believe it, but equally I want him to pay for what he’s done. “I didn’t know anything about the mortuary offences until it came out in court. I was really shocked. The police said to me, ‘Be prepared for a nasty shock’, but I wasn’t expecting anything as horric as this. I just thought it was going to be that there were other women like me, or multiple women that he was dating all at the same time. It’s been a traumatic time.”  She went on: “I was  when I began seeing him and I was with him for just over two years. “I was a district nurse and some of us used to go up to the canteen in Kent and Sussex Hospital . I was at a loose end and trying to make new friends, so I started going to the social club. I remember thinking he was quite odd for a man because he drank Archers and lemonade. “He wasn’t a beer man. He was quite a quiet man, but he was quite friendly. He just seemed like a perfectly ordinary person.”  She remembers Fuller being in a cycling club and doing the -mile London to Brighton ride. One of the club routes went directly past the dyke where he dumped murdered Caroline. Of their dates, she said: “The first outing was to the Folkestone Air Show. We once went to a Beverley Craven concert in London and he would visit me at my flat, but most of it was at the social club at the hospital. “He wasn’t the type of bloke to take me out for dinner or offer to take me anywhere particularly, but he was always pleasant and friendly. He would never get angry. It was hard to know what was going on in his head.  “He was an electrician at Kent  Sussex Hospital at the time. Sometimes when he was on call, rather than stay in his house at Broomhill Bank School, he’d stay in the nurses’ home. “I knew he was unhappy with his we. But our relationship ended because he didn’t want what I wanted and he didn’t want to be with me any more. I had to accept that he didn’t want me and he wanted someone . “I remember him saying to me that he had met another staff nurse and he was going to start seeing her.”  The woman called police last December after news of Fuller’s arrest. She explained: “When I saw his name I thought, ‘Well, Fuller is a common surname’. I looked at my phone hours later and there was a photo of him. I recognised him from the fact his eye was turning in. I was really shocked.” Fuller’s arrest came after a DNA breakthrough. A search of his home uncovered hard drives revealing prolic sexual offending of a kind no British court has seen before. Between  and , he had filmed and photographed himself sexually abusing the bodies of dozens of women and girls at the Kent and Sussex Hospital and nearby Tunbridge Wells Hospital. Fuller admitted two counts of murder at Maidstone Crown Court. He previously admitted  sexual offences, including  counts relating to  identiable mortuary victims. MPs have called for a public inquiry. And the daughter of one victim said: “It kills me to think of David Fuller’s hands on Mum in the mortuary.” Meanwhile, his shaken ex is having counselling. She added: “What he did is up there with the Moors Murderers, the Wests and Shipman. If I could eradicate it all, I would. I keep thinking, ‘Why was I so naive and stupid to get involved with someone like him ’” aposFailure to learn lessons of Savileapos - Comment, by Mark Williams-Thomas, the ex-cop who exposed Jimmy Savile The dead deserve as much dignity as the living, but David Fuller denied victims any respect whatsoever. He got away with murder for  years. Evading capture, he convinced himself he was untouchable. And, like all sex offenders, he then sought out vulnerable victims – dead women and children – to fulfil his warped sexual desires. But it is only by luck and the arrogance of Fuller that the police uncovered sexual offending as far back as  at two Kent hospitals because he kept “trophies” of his attacks and records of his abuse. In , I exposed Jimmy Savile – the DJ and TV star who sexually assaulted patients for decades across the NHS. It led to  hospitals undertaking urgent reviews.But it is clear now that lessons were not learned and, yet again, the most vulnerable in our society have been failed. In  Fuller had a criminal records check which revealed he had hidden a string of burglary convictions. Yet he stayed in post. Fuller should have been sacked immediately. So why wasn’t he  Crimes of necrophilia are extremely rare and carry a maximum jail term of just two years. Post-Savile, a review highlighted the need to reduce access to mortuaries, yet this was clearly not the case at two Kent hospitals.  When Fuller murdered Wendy and Caroline he took trophies – something he repeated will all his future victims. That brings with it considerable risk because it’s a forensic link to the victim and compelling evidence. So why take such a risk  I have no doubt Fuller kept trophies so he could relive his attacks and watch footage again, enabling him to get perverse sexual gratication. I’ve no doubt Fuller has abused many more women and young people. His offending will be far wider than hospital mortuaries. I would go much further, given that we have over , unsolved murders in the UK and everything that I know about Fuller and how offenders operate. I say with some confidence that he killed again after . title: mum visits food bank every
story: Mum visits food bank every day to feed three children despite husbands jobThe woman has gone to Feedo Needo in Digbeth, Birmingham, since the beginning of . Her husband works full-time as a lorry driver, but does not work enough to feed his familyA volunteer packs a food parcel at Feedo Needo in BirminghamByZoe ChamberlainChiara Fiorillo:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov A mum has been visiting a food bank every day for almost two years so she can feed her three children, herself and her husband. The woman has gone to Feedo Needo in Digbeth, Birmingham, since the beginning of . Her husband works full-time as a lorry driver, but despite his job, he does not earn enough to feed the whole family.Rafa Ahmed, project manager at Feedo Needo, told Birmingham Live : The parents come every day Monday to Thursday just before pm to collect sandwiches, bread, fruit, salad and snacks for their children’s school dinners the next day.Then on Fridays, they come to collect a larger food parcel that we put together for them for the whole week. It contains things like rice, milk, pasta, tins, packet meals, condiments and fruit for the children.  She added: For them, it’s become part of their daily routine. We have friendly staff and they’ve built up a rapport with them because they see them every day. They are a low income household and the children are very young. The dad works full time as a lorry driver but he doesn’t earn enough to feed the family, it’s not enough to keep the family going. He goes to work but they’re still having to rely on the food bank really heavily. This is the reality for some families. It’s something they’ve come to rely on, even though they shouldn’t have to. Feedo Needo is a charity that supports people struggling with homelessness and financial dficulty.It remained open during the first coronavirus lockdown to ensure no families went hungry.Rafa said she has seen an increase in the number of working parents and parents who have been made redundant, who simply do not have enough money to feed their children. The charity also helps people to overcome feelings of loneliness and isolation. She said: The family say it’s made such a dference to them and that they do not know what they would have done without the food bank. The mum also sometimes comes to our coffee mornings on Mondays where she can talk to others in similar situations. It’s good because people can interact with other food bank users and help each other with tips and advice. It’s nice for people to have that support, it’s good to know you’re not on your own. Feedo Needo recently won the Humanitarian Award at the Charity Today Awards, following a public vote. Rafa said: Itaposs overwhelming to see the small team at Feedo get such prestigious recognition for the amazing work they do across the Birmingham, Manchester, Bradford and London locations, helping the homeless and supporting families who have struggled financially, especially through the pandemic. Everything that we do would not be possible without our incredible volunteers and local partners and we cannot thank them enough for their continued efforts. While the next few months may be challenging, we want people to know that we can offer essential support through free food parcels, essential toiletries and multi-faceted community help.To find out more, and to donate to Feedo Needo, you can click here.Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON HomelessnessCoronavirusFood banks" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: queen novel way eating bananas
story: Queen has novel way of eating bananas so she doesnt look like a gobbling monkeyAccording to a former royal chef, the Queen refuses to peel a banana like the rest of us and has a more unusual technique for eating the fruit Image: Getty ImagesByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Nov | commentsEating a banana while trying to look elegant can prove to be quite dficult - but not for the Queen. Thataposs because according to a former royal chef she has an unusual technique for eating the fruit so she doesnapost look like a gobbling monkey. Unlike the rest of us, Her Majesty refuses to peel and then eat it, instead, she peels it with a kne and fork. According to Darren McGrady, who once worked in the royal kitchens, the Queen would cut the top and bottom off, then slice the skin away -ways. She then chopped it up into small pieces before eating them with a fork.  Being strict about the way she eats bananas isnapost the Queenaposs only food quirk. She will never eat or serve, garlic - even on formal occasions. Although she has good reasons behind this - itaposs because the royal family have to meet and greet so many people so never wants the smell of garlic on her breath. Shellfish is also a no go area as itaposs one of the foods most likely to cause food poisoning. However, it was recently reported the Queen has given up one of her nightly habits when it comes to food and drink.  Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. Sheaposs now believed to be foregoing her nightly cocktail on the advice of doctors so she is as healthy as possible. It was said that the Queen, , enjoyed a martini most evenings although she is rarely seen drinking in public and isnapost a big drinker. But it is now thought Her Majesty is shunning alcohol altogether - except for at special occasions. Her decision to give up booze is not linked to any health issues and a palace source said: It is a recent and personal decision by the Queen. Meanwhile, a family friend told Vanity Fairaposs royal correspondent Katie Nicholl: The Queen has been told to give up her evening drink which is usually a martini. It’s not really a big deal for her, she is not a big drinker but it seems a trle unfair that at this stage in her le she’s having to give up one of very few pleasures.” Comment MORE ON The QueenRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news salt-bae-abandons-ridiculously-priced-"Salt Bae serves customer a £ gold-wrapped burgerBySeren HughesTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsCelebrity chef Salt Bae has revealed heaposs leaving London after a short stay to set up his th restaurant in Saudi Arabia. Famous for his video and pics with the rich and famous, Salt Bae, whose real name is Nusret Gökçe, is often seen flamboyantly cutting up expensive steaks and sprinkling salt.But having been in London to launch a new high profile restaurant, where diners have shown bills of £,, he is now heading off again back to the Middle East, reported MyLondon. He took to his Instagram stories to announce that Sunday will be his final day in London before he heads to Riyadh.“Sunday is my last day in London. I will go to Riyadh to open my th restaurant,” Salt Bae wrote.  He added: “Sunday is my last day in Lovely London. I want to see you beautul people before I go.” Although only in London for a short time he has hit the headlines with many wealthy guests having been keen to attend the restaurant . Since his London restaurant opened on September , people with the money have turned up to have the Salt Bae treatment. But there have also been negative news about the opulence and extreme prices.  One diner took to social media to show the £, bill for dinner at his Nusr-Et Steakhouse in London. The bill included a Golden Tomahawk steak at £,  Nusret Baklavaaposs - a traditional Turkish dessert typically served with Matei Radulescu, a Turkish ice cream, at a total of £, one sautéed broccoli , a portion of asparagus , three herb crusted friesand one side of mashed potato . A vintage  bottle of Petrus was £, alone, while two bottles of  Petrus were also consumed at a whopping £, - each. Not bothered by the prices, celebrities have flocked to Salt Baeaposs restaurants - among them have been Wayne Rooney, David Beckham, and Naomi Campbell.But the prices arenapost the only source of criticism. People werenapost impressed when it was revealed that Salt Bae was hiring a Chef de Partie for the same price as a corn on the cob on his menu. While others have made his gold-covered steak themselves for under £. news uk-news savvy-couple-turn-british-gas-"Campervans: UK’s ‘Coolest Campers’ discuss van conversionByDouglas Patient:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA savvy couple has renovated a British Gas van into a quirky home for £,. Laura Evans, and Ed Knight, both , set themselves a challenge of making a Caddy Maxi van into a liveable space. The couple from Kingston-upon-Thames, London, deliberately purchased a small van to show others that home on wheels doesn’t always have to be big. The ‘adventure van’ was once used for workers of an energy and home services provider but now it is kitted out with a kitchen and bed. The couple used repurposed materials such as wood and even made a skyline roof by inserting a square window. Laura, who is a shop assistant, said: “It took four months for us to rip everything out, insulate and convert it into a mini camper. “We wanted to challenge ourselves and be creative as the pandemic put a halt on our international travel plans. “The van was in excess of £,. “And it cost £, on the mechanical work and materials such as reclaimed wood for the , the bed frame and small cupboards.“We tried to cut costs as much as we can by purchasing stuff from Facebook marketplace such as Moroccan tiles for the kitchen.“But we bought the oven brand new to ensure it worked.” All appliances such as the oven with a hob, fridge with freezer, tap with an electric pump, LED lighting, l fresh water and full solar system including a leisure battery were brand new.  But the stone sink was purchased from Facebook marketplace but was too big. Laura adds: The solution was to apossinkapos our basin into the unit and let the countertop form around. We love this finish and we believe it looks better thanwe had just simply placed it on top. Just like the kitchen doors, we used Scottish Elm for our countertops but kept the live edges and Eddy cleverly used a jigsaw to cut a waney edge to follow the curvy doors at the end of each unit.  Eddy made solid Elm shaker doors in the kitchen with close weave Rattan  which is a natural cane woven material. It is a biodegradable material which looks amazing. From the outside, the blue vehicle looks like any other Volkswagen van but inside it is a shabby chic space. With a wooden ceiling and laminate flooring, the van boasts enough room for two people but one cannot stand due to the low ceiling.  Ed said: “This is an adventure van - used for sleeping and eating. Itaposs perfect for curling up in bed and watching a movie but it is built as an adventure van so not one for spending days inside. “We loved seeing people’s reaction when we have opened the door in a public place. “They always had to double-take - especiallythey see us with a meal as you would never think there is a working kitchen in it.  “We wanted to show others that you don’t need a massive van to make a home. “We still have our home comforts such as fluffy pillows and a comfy mattress but you can’t stand up.” Ed, who is a joiner, insulated the van and did most of the handy work whilst Laura focused on bargain hunting and interior. The couple spent eight hours per day over eight weeks transforming the van into a living space.  They went on to travel around Cornwall and Isle of Skye, Scotland, before selling it. Ed said: “Laura did the finishing touches too such as most of the painting, oiling and sanding. It is much better to buy an ex-service van because it has been looking after and the mileage is good. “With clever designs, you can do it cheaper - making it better in the long run. “Laura lost her job in events as a result of the pandemic in December . “She began working part-time so this gave her something more to focus on. “We spent a total of £, and made some profit when selling it on. title: take money sausage roll pie
story: ‘Take my money’ - the sausage roll pie thats been branded a ‘game changer’Potters Pies are a regular stallholder at the Ancoats Pop-Up Market and have stunned hungry fans with their latest creation in honour of chain bakery GreggsThe Potters Pies Ode to Greggs sausage roll pie Image: www.instagram potters.piesByFiona CallowBethan ShufflebothamNiche Writer:,  Nov | commentsLove pies  What about sausage rolls  Well, one bakery has created a ‘game changing’ hybrid combining the two pastry-based favourites. Potter’s Pies, in Ancoats, Manchester, has reinvented the traditional meaty treats.The mother and son baking duo, who run a regular stall at the Ancoats Pop-Up Market on Radium Street, shared the creation on theirInstagram accountto their , followers. The pastry treat is packed full of steak and gravy, before being topped with sausage rolls that are then encased within the flaky pastry lid, Chill reports.Explaining their inspiration behind the dish, Potter’s Pies said on their Instagram : “King of the steak bake and the sausage roll, weaposve combined the two into a pie to salute Greggs and all that theyaposve done for hangovers over the years. “It was touch and go as to whether this would even work, but after rolling out the sausage rolls and egg washing them into place on top of the steak - I knew it was going to be a winner!” The post attracted over  likes, with people claiming that the pie was ‘a game changer’. One user tagged a friend and said: “Get me one of these tomorrow and Iaposll hug you forever”. Another pleaded: “Take. My. Money.” A third took it even further, simply writing:‘*licks screen*”. As well as setting up stall in the market, Potter’s Pies also sell their products to a iety of local pubs and bars in the Manchester area. Their menu boasts classic offerings such as the cheese and onion pie, a corned beef hash pie, pulled pork sausage rolls and many more, as well as new seasonal specials and inventive combinations, such as the chippy sausage with salt and vinegar scraps, or the bacon, mac and blue cheese pie.Wondering where to eat, drink or visit for your next UK holiday  At Chill we help you decide where to go and stay next with hundreds of recommendations right on your doorstep. Visit our brilliant new website chill and start packing. If youaposd also like weekly inspiration and advice for your next trip, you can sign up to the Chill newsletter here. For the latest must-have travel news follow us on Instagram, Facebook and Twitter. They recently added a plant-based twist on the sausage roll pie so that veggies can get involved too, using a beef alternative and vegan sausages for the filling. Sharing the news with their followers, they wrote: “Here we go - % VEGAN aposAN ODE TO GREGGSapos. It took us all weekend but weaposve done it, and itaposs very very tasty indeed. “The apossteakapos is @unbelievablealt beef which we marinated for  hours and then slow cooked. We then add the vegan sausage rolls and bang it in the oven. “Iaposve just eaten one now for my tea and it was mega - itaposll be available alongside our meat version all the time now.” Comment MORE ON ChillFoodCity of Manchester" data-immediate"data-immediate"Fancy an escape to the Chill newsletter for weekly inspiration and advice on UK holidays Sign Up!Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: uk no longer covid capital
story: UK is no longer the Covid capital of Europe as infections finally begin to fallAustria, Belgium and Ireland have taken over Britain with their Covid- infection rate, despite having stricter policies when it comes to vaccine passports, testing and face masksThe UK is no longer the Covid capital of Europe as infections continue to drop Image: Bloomberg via Getty ImagesByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Nov | comments The UK is no longer the Covid capital of Europe, according to official data.Austria, Belgium and Ireland have taken over Britain with their infection rate, despite all three countries having stricter policies on vaccine passports and face masks.Figures from November , show how the UKaposs infection rate per million people dropped to fourth place in Western Europe, according to Our World in Data — an Oxford University-based research .The UKaposs infection rate was recorded to be . per million people compared to Austria , Belgiumand Ireland . In Austria, people must people high-grade FFP masks on public transport and essential shops. Unvaccinated iniduals must wear masks in all shops and museums, and everyone must show proof of vaccination or a negative test before entering virtually all indoor settings. Austria is also carrying out the most Covid tests in Western Europe, which could partly explain why their infection is so high. Belgium and Ireland, which are both recording higher infection rates than the UK, are testing up to two-third less than the UK. In Belgium, people are required to wear a face mask on public transport and shops, and they must show proof of vaccination or a negative test to enter all hospitality and fitness venues.  In Ireland, the number of households that can meet indoors is capped to three for vaccinated families and unvaccinated people are only able to meet indoors with one vaccinated household at once. Infections in the UK appear to be dropping as a total of , new daily cases were recorded on Saturday, a . per cent fall on last weekaposs figures.  Daily cases appear to have fallen sharply compared to the , recorded on Saturday, October . It comes as the Tory government has continued to ignore plans to bring in aposPlan Bapos measures ahead of winter, despite warnings from scientists. Last week, Sir Patrick Vallance said the UK was still in a very uncertain phase of the pandemic - and the Government needed to be ready to act quicklythe situation worsens.  for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information atwww.mirror email.The Chief Scientic Adviser said Plan B measures needed to remain on the table and ministers need to push beyond natural reluctance to impose new Covid curbs. The Governmentaposs Covid Winter plan contains a list of contingency measuresthe virus begins to surge, known as plan B. These include making face masks mandatory in some settings, vaccine passports and ordering people to work from home. title: uk weather forecast map shows
story: UK weather forecast: Map shows Tropical Storm Wanda barrelling towards BritainThe Met Office is tracking Tropical Storm Wanda which is on its way towards the UK and is expected to bring unsettled weather when its remnants reach Britains shoresA map shows Tropical Storm Wanda over the Atlantic barrelling towards BritainByDouglas Patient:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA map shows Tropical Storm Wanda over the Atlantic barrelling towards Britain as mph gales and heavy rain batter the country this weekend. It is forecast to bring sustained winds to the UK by Tuesday and a US National Hurricane Centre map shows it headed right for the country. This comes as there is currently a yellow warning for wind in place for northern Scotland until pm on Sunday. The warning states: Strengthening west to north westerly winds will bring gusts of -mph perhaps locally mph, to exposed locations of northern Scotland. “These winds initially across the Western Isles and north west mainland Scotland on Saturday evening, spreading to the north east mainland and Orkney overnight and Sunday morning. “In combination with high spring tides this is expected to lead to large waves around the coasts. Winds gradually easing through Sunday afternoon.” Britain is set for more unsettled next week as remnants of Tropical Storm Wanda arrive from Tuesday. Met Office forecaster Dan Harris said: “Tropical Storm Wanda is not too far from the UK - and may indirectly influence the forecast early next week.”Netweather and STV forecaster Jo Farrow added: “If Wanda gets caught up with another Atlantic low pressure, its tropical energy could help bring wet and windy weather to the UK.”It is currently over the Atlantic Ocean and will move north eastwards during the course of the weekend. On Sunday night Wanda is expected to weaken and be downgraded to a non-tropical feature, and what is left of the storm will become embedded within a larger Atlantic frontal zone, the Met Office said.  This will then move across the UK on Tuesday and Wednesday. The Met Office said it could lead to rainfall and potentially weather warnings - although the timing and track of the system is still uncertain. UK forecast for next five days Today: Windy, especially across northern and eastern Scotland where gales or severe gales and high gusts expected. Many areas will be dry with sunny spells, but some showers are likely in the north and west and the Midlands. Colder than yesterday. Tonight: Daytime showers fading this evening leaving many areas dry and chilly with clear spells overnight. Turning cloudier with rain at times in the west later. Becoming less windy. Monday: Bright at first in the south and east, then turning cloudier later but remaining mainly dry. Cloudier and windier in the north and west with rain at times, especially later. Outlook for Tuesday to Thursday: Cloud and rain moving southeast through Tuesday with blustery showers following in the north. Cloud and outbreaks of rain in the south likely ing north midweek. Mild in the south.
